answer_html: \(u(t)=\begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} e^{6t} + \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix} e^{-t}\) Finally, since one of the eigenvalues is positive, the differential equation is unstable.
hints_html:
Start by writing the differential equation in matrix form u’ = Au.

If the eigenvalues of the corresponding matrix A are distinct, then the general solution of the linear differential equation is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle u(t) = c_1 v_1 e^{\lambda_1 t} + c_2 v_2 e^{\lambda_2 t}\end{aligned}\]

where v1 and v2 are eigenvectors corresponding to the eigenvalues \(\lambda\)1 and \(\lambda\)2, respectively, and c1, c2 are constants.

Next, use the initial condition to solve for the constants c1 and c2.

Finally, the stability is determined by the sign of the (real part of the) eigenvalues.
hints_latex:
Start by writing the differential equation in matrix form \emph{u' =
Au}.

Next, use the initial condition to solve for the constants
\emph{c\textsubscript{1}} and \emph{c\textsubscript{2}}.

Finally, the stability is determined by the sign of the (real part of
the) eigenvalues.
hints_raw:
Start by writing the differential equation in matrix form ''u' = Au''.
If the eigenvalues of the corresponding matrix ''A'' are distinct, then the general solution of the linear differential equation is given by

:<math>\displaystyle u(t) = c_1 v_1 e^{\lambda_1 t} + c_2 v_2 e^{\lambda_2 t}</math>

where ''v<sub>1</sub>'' and ''v<sub>2</sub>'' are eigenvectors corresponding to the eigenvalues ''&lambda;<sub>1</sub>'' and ''&lambda;<sub>2</sub>'', respectively, and ''c<sub>1</sub>, c<sub>2</sub>'' are constants.
Next, use the initial condition to solve for the constants ''c<sub>1</sub>'' and ''c<sub>2</sub>''.
Finally, the stability is determined by the sign of the (real part of the) eigenvalues.
sols_html:
To begin with we rewrite the system in matrix form:

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} x'(t) \\ y'(t) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 4 \\ 3 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x(t) \\ y(t) \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and call this matrix A. We need the eigenvalues of A and hence find the zeros of the characteristic polynomials

\[\begin{aligned} \det(A-\lambda I) &= \det\left(\begin{bmatrix} 3-\lambda & 4 \\ 3 & 2-\lambda \end{bmatrix}\right) \\ &= (3-\lambda)(2-\lambda)-12 \\ &= \lambda^2 - 5\lambda -6 \\ &= (\lambda-6)(\lambda+1)\end{aligned}\]

We see that \(\lambda\)1 = 6 and \(\lambda\)2 = -1.

Next, we calculate corresponding eigenvectors. For \(\lambda\)1 = 6 we find the eigenvectors in the null space of \(\begin{bmatrix} -3 & 4 \\ 3 & -4 \end{bmatrix}\) e.g. \(v_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\). Similarly, for \(\lambda\)2 = -1 we find the eigenvectors in the null space of \(\begin{bmatrix} 4 & 4 \\ 3 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\) e.g. \(v_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}\). Hence, the general solution of the linear differential equation is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} x(t) \\ y(t) \end{bmatrix} = c_1 \begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} e^{6t} + c_2 \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix} e^{-t}\end{aligned}\]

To find the values of the constants c1 and c2 we plug in the values at the initial condition t = 0:

\[\begin{aligned} x(0) &= 6 &= 4c_1 + c_2 \\ y(0) &= 1 &= 3c_1 - c_2\end{aligned}\]

which has the solution c1 = 1, c2 = 2. Therefore, the full solution of the linear differential equation with the given initial conditions is

\[\begin{aligned} u(t) = \begin{bmatrix} x(t) \\ y(t) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} e^{6t} + \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix} e^{-t}\end{aligned}\]

Finally, since one of the eigenvalues is positive, the differential equation is unstable.
statement_html:
Consider the linear differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} x'(t) &= 3x(t) + 4y(t)\\ y'(t) &= 3x(t) + 2y(t)\end{aligned}\]

with the initial conditions \(\displaystyle x(0) = 6\), \(\displaystyle y(0) = 1\). Find the solution \(\displaystyle u(t) = (x(t),y(t))^{T}\) and determine the stability of the differential equation.
statement_latex:
Consider the linear differential equation

\begin{align*}
x'(t) &= 3x(t) + 4y(t)\\
y'(t) &= 3x(t) + 2y(t)
\end{align*}

with the initial conditions $\displaystyle x(0) = 6$,
$\displaystyle y(0) = 1$. Find the solution
$\displaystyle u(t) = (x(t),y(t))^{T}$ and determine the stability of
the differential equation.
statement_raw:
Consider the linear differential equation

:<math>
\begin{align}
x'(t) &= 3x(t) + 4y(t)\\
y'(t) &= 3x(t) + 2y(t)\\
\end{align}
</math>

with the initial conditions <math> \displaystyle x(0) = 6 </math>, <math> \displaystyle y(0) = 1 </math>. Find the solution <math> \displaystyle u(t) = (x(t),y(t))^{T}</math> and determine the stability of the differential equation.
